Title: Unleash Your Inner Star with this Spectacular Avatar Magic! - My Review of "FaceRig"

When it comes to transforming your virtual presence into something out of a sci-fi movie, "FaceRig" is the game that has us all shouting, "Beam me up, Scotty!" This mind-blowing creation from the geniuses at Holotech Studios takes the concept of avatar customization to a whole new dimension. Forget about the mundane world of video conferencing – "FaceRig" is your ticket to becoming a digital sensation, a cosmic explorer, or a fantastical creature, all from the comfort of your own home.

"FaceRig" invites you to immerse yourself in a mesmerizing universe where your facial expressions are the key to unlocking boundless creativity. The game provides a dazzling array of avatars, ranging from cute and cuddly animals to otherworldly beings with cosmic powers. Whether you aspire to be a majestic dragon, a mischievous fox, or even a cyberpunk hacker, "FaceRig" has got you covered. The attention to detail in each avatar is jaw-dropping, making it a visual feast for both the player and the audience.

One of the most remarkable features of "FaceRig" is its intuitive and seamless control system. Using a webcam, the game tracks your facial expressions with remarkable precision, translating every smile, frown, or raised eyebrow onto your chosen avatar. The responsive tracking and real-time animation are so fluid that you'll find yourself losing track of reality as you become fully engrossed in your character's digital skin.

"FaceRig" isn't just about looking cool; it's about having a blast! You can use this platform to unleash your inner actor, bringing your character to life with your expressions and voice. Imagine hosting virtual events, streaming, or just goofing around with friends while transformed into a fantastical creature. The possibilities for fun and creativity are as limitless as the cosmos itself.

The game's streaming integration allows you to share your avatar-driven adventures with the world. Engage with your audience on platforms like Twitch, YouTube, or any streaming service you prefer. "FaceRig" is more than just a game; it's a ticket to stardom in the digital age!

Holotech Studios doesn't rest on its laurels. "FaceRig" is a living, breathing entity that continues to evolve with regular updates and new avatar packs. Plus, the community around the game is both welcoming and incredibly creative, with users continually inventing new ways to use the software. Whether you're a casual user or a hardcore content creator, "FaceRig" has something for everyone.

With "FaceRig", you're not just gaming; you're exploring a kaleidoscope of emotions. You'll find yourself laughing, crying, and feeling genuinely connected to your virtual alter ego and your audience. It's a transformative experience that bridges the gap between the digital and physical worlds like never before.

In conclusion, "FaceRig" is nothing short of spectacular. It's a portal to a universe where you can be anyone or anything you've ever dreamed of, and it's an absolute joy to use. With its stunning avatars, intuitive controls, and endless potential for fun and creativity, "FaceRig" is a must-have for anyone who wants to turn their digital presence into a thrilling adventure. So, step into the virtual spotlight and let your imagination run wild with "FaceRig" – the future of avatar customization is here, and it's truly out of this world!

115912828.review:
After almost 8 years of using this daily, I'll be moving on.

Upsides
1) The advanced tracking settings allows for a lot of fine tuning and the keybinds are a necessity when it comes to making the avatar come to life. 
2) Auto blink and auto eye movement as this software struggles hard with eye tracking through glasses.
3) Some great default avatars and some small customizations to make them more personal!

The downsides 
1) Not supported anymore, you're on your own kids. (This is a big one)
2) Limited props available
3) Tracking is marginal at best for users with glasses
4) Lack of integration with streaming services/alert providers
5) No longer for sale
6) Holotech moved to a new (different) version due to a struggling business model

The next version of Facerig is Animaze... but personally I will be moving to Vtube Studio with a custom 2D rig. I've tried both extensively, and I'm not a fan of the new software or avatars. Frankly, the uncertainty of what will happen with this version as it ages in addition to the limited functionality in terms of props/engagement features means, I'm going 2D baby!

107648157.review:
Was pretty good although with its' quirks. Being that the successor to this [being Animaze] does not support usage of the Intel RealSense Development kit for hand tracking this is (or rather was) your only option. This alone comes with its' own quirks and would only be stable with an Intel 4th Generation or newer cpu because of the dev kit requirement (trust me, I spent months trying to stabilize it on multiple AMD systems to no avail). Had to get a refund once before on this product because of this reason although have repurchased it duringt he final sale as it was the applications last "hurrah" to redeem itself. Finally got it stable on an Intel i3-6100T based HP EliteDesk 800 G2 Mini and have been thus far pretty satisfied.

Aside from that issue, it worked pretty well out of the box when the RealSense wasn't used. Ensure you have a camera that has good quality to avoid fuzzing of the UlSee detection and to an extent good lighting. You should then not have much issue with needing to tweak the animation region limits or the camera exposure. Even lighting is best here such as strong diffused background lighting behind a monitor or a quality ring light of sorts.

100266824.review:
FaceRig is buy to play software for animating virtual characters using your webcam.  It worked on Win 10, looked good, played good, sounded ?  There is some Free DLC, but the rest of the DLC in the store cost some money. 

 FaceRig by default is Classic the base version of FaceRig, "which allows for home non-profit use and even limited monetization on YouTube/Twitch or similar as long as the commercial aspect of it is not significant. We consider commercially significant using it on any avenue (channel) that produces you more than $500 monthly revenue. This includes ad-based revenue and voluntary donations (one time or recurrent such as a Patreon). If you are under this threshold you can use Classic, if you are above you need to upgrade to Pro or Studio. "   

Has 37 steam achievements. workshop and trading cards.  You can have more than one character on the screen.  Has Live2D module in DLC and the workshop has plenty of Live2D avatars.

CONS:  
- The devs had ended development on this software to work on Animaze instead.
- Does not have animated body and hands.

Maybe get this on sale, but if you are a new VTuber, you should try it out the classic version before you pull the trigger on the FaceRig Pro DLC.  The devs new product Animaze might be better, if you have money to throw at it.

99721326.review:
Overall, FaceRig is pretty good, depending on what you need it for.
If you're just looking to have fun with it, use during Zoom meetings, or with friends, it's totally awesome and you should grab it!

If you're looking to create content (Vtubing), you *might* want to look for something a bit nicer or newer. I tried out Animaze, but was not impressed at all. However, my vtuber model was sent as a "Facerig ready" file, so I used this instead of other things. In the future, I'll probably look for something else, unless Animaze becomes good, or Facerig gets a fresh coat of paint with some QoL improvements. I was also pretty upset that my model didn't work properly in Animaze, given they're basically the same program. I didn't like Animaze when I tried it out, but maybe I would with some improvements, but I can't do it if the model I paid out the ass for doesn't work in it.

It's not bad, it's just definitely outdated-feeling. You can't project a widget like other programs, no transparent background, etc.. For some reason, it also pushes my computer to its limits. 
Worst of all though, the face tracking is abhorrent. I have to put my hair up and in a headband for my face to be tracked, and if you have glasses, forget about it, it's not happening. And when it does happen, your character constantly looks like they're having a stroke. If you do manage to get a non-stroking out character that is being tracked, you have to stay very, very, VERY still! One slight movement or adjustment and boom, you lose tracking.

Despite that, Facerig looks like it might be the best option for people just getting into content making/vtubing, definitely look up some tutorials on how to get your model into a program like OBS, and familiarize yourself with it. I know I said a lot of critical things, but that's mainly because they're things I wish I would have known going in, and things I wish I knew before buying a model made for Facerig, and not another program.

Update: 
I originally wasn't recommending the game as it didn't appear to be playable on Windows 10 machines, but I was finally able to resolve the issue. You have to uninstall all of the MS Visual C++ redistributables and then install each one again. The game won't launch on Windows 10 without doing this as there's some issue with it needing the 2015 redist, but Windows not being able to install it because it doesn't need it. So you need to reinstall all of them starting with the earliest version.

The game is as slow to track mouth movements as I remember, but I'll chalk that up to my PCs not being top of the line since other people aren't complaining about that. The number of avatars available and customizations have been greatly expanded since I originally used the software. While I won't be buying the new version as I just got this for fun, I can recommend the software for hobbyists.

================================
Game doesn't work on newer PC's.

I had some fun playing this on my Windows 7 PC, but didn't work on my Windows 10 PC on install.

After spending a few hours uninstalling, reinstalling, verifying FaceRig install files (with their own tool), scouring help and community forums (it appears a lot of other users are having this same issue), going through multiple SteamApps folders and reinstalling various redistributables it still isn't working. If the intent of the FaceRig devs was to break a working product so that you'd have to buy their newer version of the exact same thing then they failed because I'm not going to pay for a product again that I already own.

84299180.review:
FaceRig definitely is a lot of fun especially for streaming - the software lends itself to doing so. On its own, unless you have a really good reason to have it, the investment is probably not worth it - this program is less a game and is more of a tool than anything else. Of course, if you just want to have fun with a face tracker and see yourself as certain characters, go right ahead! There are other alternatives that are more cost-effective for that end. But this is higher end in terms of facial tracking and facerig makes it relatively simple to import new avatars if you commissioned/designed any (however, I wish that more documentation was provided on how to do this because questions about these cannot be found in any facerig resource and is usually found on forums or videos made by other users - the process of doing so is pretty easy but it is very unclear). 

The only warning that I have is for amateur streamers - no matter what settings you might dial down, THIS PROGRAM CONSUMES A LOT OF YOUR RESOURCES. Load-wise this is essentially another game and if your PC isn't up to snuff, you will experience a lot of FPS drops, crashes, and stutters. 

Have fun!

78940532.review:
I bought Facerig a few years back, and have streamed on twitch using it exclusively. With over 4000 hours streaming with Facerig, I must say that I am very impressed. It is perfect for helping someone bypass many of the insecurities they might have getting started streaming. I am a black cat with purple eyes, and I have several outfits I often change into (off screen, NO PEEKING!) depending on the game I am playing, viewer request, or my mood. I wear a viking hat when playing medieval games like skyrim or conan. When I play Farm simulator, I have a floppy sun hat and a bubble pipe (with bubbles constantly spewing from the pipe) and I call myself "Farmer kitteh Jebeddaih". When I play 7 days to die I wear my over-sized (for a cat) football helmet that happens to have a hatchet stuck in the side of it.

I have so much fun streaming with facerig, and its also a great gag when answering a skype or discord video call! Yes, there  are some situations that can mess up the face tracking, and if your computer is already struggling to run your game and stream it too, running facerig on standard settings can push your cpu over the edge, but with 4000 hours of experience, a little common sense, and a little trial and error, I have learned many ways to minimize or negate 90% of these sorts of issues and others that many people complain about. Just keep in mind that most of the issues people have are very situational, and can be solved if you are willing. Yes, sitting in a dark room with the only light in the room coming from your monitor and glaring straight off your glasses will most likely cause facerig to lose track of your eyes! :O. Solutions to this problem can include things like turning on more ambient lights in the room which can drastically reduce the intensity of the monitor glare off your glasses, or moving the camera or light source location  so the reflection isn't directed at the camera... or my personal solution, the last set of glasses I chose to get small lenses, and when I Facerig, I have my glasses a little low on my nose, and i have my camera on top of my monitor, and my camera can see my eyes over the top rim of my glasses instead of through the lenses. Also if my tracking starts getting janky it might be a sign that I need to trim my mustache and beard neatly away from my lips. Finally and possibly the most important thing I have learned is the delicate art of imitation calibration. If your avatar is looking down too much, look down a bit like the avatar is, and re-calibrate head position, then when you look back up normally, your avatar will do the same. If my avatar is squinting or closing its eyes a lot, its usually mostly because my camera is high and sees more upper eyelid from that angle and interprets that as them half closed. My solution is to partly close my eyes like 20% (in a relaxed way like i'm sleepy, not tense and squinty) and I re-calibrate expressions, and then open eyes normally, and so does my avatar. I know there are settings that you can change thresholds and positions in, but if I am streaming and playing a game it takes like 2 seconds (after practice) to mimic my avatar and hit the correct re-calibration button (I have facerig on my other monitor), instead of fiddling with menus and sliders mid stream. Occasionally if I shift in my chair or reach for something my avatar gets all out of wack, maybe leaned way left when I am sitting up straight. One of the fastest fixes that often works is to put up a paw (cuz I'm a cat) to interrupt the camera's view of my face, so it loses tracking, and the avatar goes into neutral centered straight default position, and then I put my paw down, camera re-acquires my face tracking and all is good.

My point of this massive rambling (besides throwing out some potentially useful things to try if you are having these issues) is to point out that yes, the program can have some issues at times under certain circumstances, but if you take the time to think about what could be causing the issue instead of just deciding that the tracking is crappy or whatever, you can probably work out a reasonable solution or compromise that will help to make it behave better. I've seen posts where people "had to shave off their beard" and similar things. Obviously that can certainly help but often such extremes are not necessary. Trimming is usually enough, but in some rare cases the program might confuse your reddish mustache with your lips... or your "mileage may vary" due to other circumstances that are amplifying the issue like bad lighting, shadows, camera model, camera settings like gamma correction... etc.

I am more than happy to have anyone send me a steam message if they would like me to help them troubleshoot a problem or teach them how to reduce CPU load while losing as little effective quality as possible, set up an avatar to be unique, or just give them the full starter crash course to save them the frustration many users have the first couple weeks, or anything else I can share from my thousands of hours of practical experience.

Lastly, I would like to mention (as if I haven't said enough) that the fact that facerig is being discontinued, and alot of people are saying they are abandoning facerig do not buy and all that. If you get facerig while you still can, you get to use it forever, as long as it works at least, without having to pay the subscription for the new rebuilt version called Animaze. You will get a discount on animaze if you do choose to use it and have facerig already. You get extra animaze stuff if you had facerig before launch... Yes they will stop improving and updating facerig but $15 for unlimited use and bonus anamaze content? Seems worth it to me.

78520518.review:
For the basic stuff just to have fun with the avatars that are included and L2D avatar/workshop, I'd say it is fine. Not more.

This review is if you want to go beyond the standard and try more advanced stuff.

[b]Custom avatars:[/b]
Since I have been using it for a while, I had major problems just to get my VRChat/Beat saber imported. 
Mostly I got Assert Fail, reading it would be something with the mesh, then I figured out it was the bones. No idea why. 
Removed, added some bones and then it imported, it complained about the mesh having too much tris/verts/polygons so I removed the most of the avatar that was not in view and import succeeded... Just to have FaceRig crash after selecting the avatar.

Their documentation on importing  says some basic stuff about the shaders and required bones, and their videoguide isn't great either since most of the user base will be using blender. Not some expensive Maya or other pricey 3d modelling tool.

Blender guides are out there but most of them were with basic shapes and not with a fullblown avatar.
The import software isn't great and a big hassle, not user friendly at all 'name x as y' etc, the import scripts are quite, weird.

It's a pain.. and so not user friendly. Next to that, they are removing this for a subscription based model. Thanks to someone I heard about another program called VSeeFace, took me only 30 minutes to have my avatar as stock for VRChat fully working inside VSeeFace, no importing hassle or whatsoever, few clicks, setup the right blendshapes and you're done. That's how you can do it, much much easier and worst is Free. Of course no support unlike FaceRig, but seeing that's dying anyway for FaceRig and having the ease of '2 clicks' import makes me go away from FaceRig and not even think about Animaze, which is FaceRig, but with subscription. (Yes once Animaze comes out, this disappears completely).

[b]Hand Tracking[/b]
Their hand tracking is also a bit garbage, often it fails to read LEAP (the previous mentioned software has way less issue with it and it is 'close to perfect') They also added support for the RealSense Camera, but... only for the old one, and they are not updating to the new SDK. 

[b]anyway...[/b]
It's their biggest mistake to go Animaze and go subscription based, because there are free alternatives out there. Free alternatives may have flaws such as 'no support' (but hey community support is something!), or the lack of adding props (hm, obs has Image Layers so there is an easy alternative. And when you do avatars, it is easy just to get a new outfit and hats etc), but importing avatars without having too much hassle? I take that. 

[b]TLDR[/b]
I do not recommend, and I step also away from FaceRig.
Bye FaceRig, good concept, but poorly executed.

I'd rate it 6.5/10.

if you thought that Joke was inappropriate, wait until you see my draft

Anyway, if you’re looking for FaceRig, then you probably already know what it is and what it does. If you suffer from dementia or something, here’s a refresher. It takes a camera input, does some face tracking magic to it, put it into a 3D Model/Live2D avatar, and output it as a video/stream. There’s other software that can do this, but Considering how old FaceRig is, I’d consider it to be the easiest, most feature rich, and most accessible (the fact that It has a community constantly uploading models also helps) compared to other options (unless you have an entire company developing their own version of course). That being said, you do need the Live2D module DLC to use about 99% of the community uploaded stuff, and I’m pretty sure 99% of the time, that’s what you’re going to use this for.
All resource and documentation can be searched online. Use it to turn whatever 2d Fantasy you’re dreaming every night. Use a voice changer if you want to add to the effect. You should preferably buy it on discount, although it’s pretty reasonably priced nonetheless. Cheers.

68092731.review:
You know, back when FaceRig came out in 2015, I found it to be pretty neat and cool, and somewhat functioned as intended. However, as of my most recent experience, it has brought me great shame and disappointment; sheer anger even.  

When I installed and booted up this program I was greeted with a 17 step setup that required me to install 3 separate 3rd party programs to finish the setup, one of which completely tourso-grinded my audio drivers, and the other two turned my computer into the equivalent to that of a shitty single slice toaster. Beyond all of that, the software wouldn't even start when I tried to boot it through their launcher; so I did what any normal person would do in this situation, uninstall the software. But here's the problem, what about the other 3 pieces of shit programs that had to be installed just for fancy shmancy facial recognition software, that didn’t make it work run off to? It wasn't uninstalled that's for sure. And why the fuck does my computer still run like hot trash? that's a good question, task manager doesn't seem to know, guess I'll just fuck myself. 

I remember when I first used this program back in 2015, the facial recognition wasn’t the best, and as far as I’ve seen to date, there hasn’t been too many improvements, if any. Every now and then the avatar will appear to have a lazy eye if the users eyes aren’t open enough, and sometimes appear to be having a stroke, or that 1000 mile stare. Unless the user has a pristine face, with over exaggerated features, I think the avatars would work just fine. But anything other than that, the program might have a serious problem with it. Seems kinda face-ist if you ask me. 

Now in the year 2020, I never thought I would see pictures load from the top down; from what felt like a 5 minute google search. After I installed and then uninstalled this piece of shit software, I was greeted with the nostalgic feeling of the early 2000's. I honestly wouldn't be surprised if it made me install some sort of malware, or even started using my computer to mine crypto, because that's what it felt like. one hard reset on my computer that took longer than it should have seemed to fix my problem of crippling processing speeds, it was almost like my computer went to get lobotomized, but ended up getting sodomized instead. The sheer inconvenience of a facial recognition software pegging my computer in every way possible, not doing what was promised, had truly invigorated me to make this review. 

Words don't describe how I feel about this program, I’d have to be some nihilistic fuck freak that suffered from some serious head trauma to even enjoy this program. I wouldn’t recommend this program if it was the last facial recognition software on earth, especially in the state that it's in. The fact that it isn't compatible with pre-installed Realteck audio drivers, makes me question what the fuck went wrong in the development of this program. Seriously it's facial recognition software, not a god damn soundboard. What the fuck does FaceRig need to transmit audio for, and why do I need to install shitty 3rd party software for it anyway, why couldn't the audio drivers come with the program? Again, why does it even need the audio drivers? Something here doesn’t seem to be adding up, but that might just be me.

Another thing that really bothers me is the lack of a community workshop, something that this type of software should have, and would benefit from having; a feature that should have been implemented a long time ago. It would have something more to offer the community, but instead it’s a dollar or more for a pack of characters, if not one avatar. doesn't seem right to me given the price of the base program. On top of the base program there’s the pro and studio versions, and reading the description for the pro version alone, makes me feel like my bottom end is being reamed for all it's worth; giving no technical advancements/improvements in terms of the base program, and as far as I'm aware it's for people that are “making profit” off of the classic version, or are using it for commercial use. if someone’s making more than $500 a month while using the classic software, they must now spend part of their next paycheck on their knees to face rig, and then on some licensing that doesn’t seem to come along with it. Also as far as I'm aware - as the description doesn't say anything about it - the DLC avatars don't come with the pro software, so there’s more cock sucking action that may need to be commenced, just to add some avatars to the users arsenal. As if they haven’t spent enough.

Now I can vaguely understand the reasoning behind not having a community workshop for the program, due to people making avatars of licensed characters from movies and what not, perhaps something that could get the company into trouble, or maybe even hinder the reputation, but there's a bunch of other products out there that have a community workshop, and as far as I'm aware they haven't gotten into any serious shenanigans. Looking at something like VR chat, it may not be a facial recognition software, but there’s a lot of impressive avatars made by the community that could get someone into a lot of trouble. Even with that, I’m sure implementing some sort of filter, or verification system, would be better than not having any community involvement at all, perhaps having some sort of event for who can make the best avatar, would be going in a step in the right direction, in terms of building a bigger community. 

I think that this program still has a long way to go, and hasn’t really changed a whole lot since it’s release, maybe a few patches that helped with facial recognition, but I personally don’t see much of an improvement. I can say with certainty that FaceRig will not be the end all be all in terms of facial recognition software that turns people into an avatar. I can see some other company coming in, and offering more to the table then FaceRig has currently. I don’t fully agree with the price, or  the terms of HoloTech, it seems to me like they’re trying to milk their program for all it’s worth. I don’t see a problem with asking for more with the Pro versions, but I think that when someone is making at least $500 just for using FaceRig, even though it may have little to nothing to do with that money is a little bit of a stretch, and asking for more than 10% of that for the pro version is kinda bullshit. But that’s just business.

TLDR; I think this program is a steaming pile of dogshit, that needs some sort of community workshop/involvement, better facial recognition technology, better price for what you get and not have mandatory third party software that bricks your computer.

Unless someone has access to a time machine that goes back to when FaceRig first came out, and the technology had that wow factor. I cannot recommend this software to anyone, for any reason at all. If I could refund this I 100% would, but I’m afraid I’m more than a few years past the expiry on that one.

1.5/10 Not enough anime titties, or jiggle physics

55750717.review:
TL;DR: Very tough to recommend with long bangs, long facial hair, or narrow eyes. However it's certainly usable even with those.

We recommend this with some caveats. It actually tracks fairly good with a 1080p camera. The eyes look fantastic even with semi long eyelashes and the blink tracking works pretty darn well. The head tracking is also pretty fantastic, however tilting your head forward or back can also affect how other parts of the face are scanned for 2D avatars. Looking up might make your character open it's mouth for instance. Though the program is pretty flexible with it's advanced tracking configuration. So messing around with that can make it a lot less noticeable for 3D avatars. Long bangs can get in the way of eyebrow tracking, so it's advised to tie hair back or trim bangs. Mustache hair can get in the way of mouth tracking, so shape it up or pair it down. Narrow eyes make it a tad harder for it to notice eye movements, but only marginally so.

For the best experience we highly recommend trying to customize as much as you can yourself after you set the "auto configure". Each person we used had a different face and required some settings to be changed. Also, remember that you can save auto tracking configurations to be used later. However, note that some avatars work better with different configurations. For instance, some 2D avatars don't use a lot of the body movements, but the 3D avatars do. 

Hand tracking and tongue tracking is also possible with the IR Real Sense intel camera, but we have yet to get one. Will update review once we manage to pick one up.

51477895.review:
I have a pretty powerful gaming rig with latest, greatest drivers. I'll just start with that. And even with that powerful rig and just doing a local video recording (streaming not activated) this software struggles. The developer will tell you the following:

"Adding FaceRig to your streaming configuration (stream software + game) will add some CPU/GPU load. Note that face tracking and high quality rendering come with the CPU and GPU resource cost, so if you are running a game at high quality graphics option, you may have frame drops.

There are some things that you can do to make FaceRig footprint smaller on your setup:
1. use FaceRig at a lower resolution, you can go as low as 960x540. I assume you are using FaceRig as webcam view, so the view is already small.
2. use a lower setting in the game you are streaming, after all, you are basically streaming two games (resource wise)
3. use window capture instead of FaceRig Virtual Webcam and disable Broadcast. There is an option to hide the interface.
4. limit FaceRig's refresh rate to 24-30 fps. Go to General Options > Performance Tab.
5. Camera resolution needs to be low (General Options > Resolution)."

Those settings do help some but they do not get you to a point where the software works without looking like Max Headroom with a significant audio delay timing with your lips moving. The tracking has to be calibrated constantly and you will spend 10.8 hours tweaking settings.

I got this on a Humble Bundle sale but even still I cannot recommend using this software. The technology just isn't quite there yet and I feel like Holotech Studios needs to hit their labs with some test machines, run some tests with OBS and try streaming.

51447430.review:
I kickstarted this project years ago. Yet somehow never got around to reviewing it. 
It started the facial software that is now used -everywhere-. After Facerig kicked off, intel began promoting their version (which was vastly inferior) and other companies followed suit until now the software has been taken to casual social media platforms. It's amazing to see how much pull this project had, and I'm proud to have been some small part of it. 
It's fun, it's niche, and it's not something that everyone HAS to have. But it's opened up a lot of avenues for those of us who are camera shy, who like to have something amazing to show off, and who want to show a different side to the world. 
Facial transformation software is everywhere now, but Facerig was the OG, and it deserves a lot of love for that.

51195604.developer_response:
Hi, for the tracker to properly work, you have to have enough light in your room so that your face will be clearly visible. As for the FPS drop, that might happen if you use both FaceRig and the other game with high settings; adding FaceRig to your streaming configuration (stream software + game) will add some CPU/GPU load. Face tracking and high quality rendering come with the CPU and GPU resource cost, so if you are running a game at high quality graphics option, you may have frame drops.

There are some things that you can do to make FaceRig footprint smaller on your setup:
1. use FaceRig at a lower resolution, you can go as low as 960x540. I assume you are using FaceRig as webcam view, so the view is already small.
2. use a lower setting in the game you are streaming, after all, you are basically streaming two games (resource wise)
3. use window capture instead of FaceRig Virtual Webcam and disable Broadcast. There is an option to hide the interface.
4. limit FaceRig's refresh rate to 24-30 fps. Go to General Options > Performance Tab.
5. Camera resolution needs to be low (General Options > Resolution).

51088900.review:
Already worth it. Going to use the pseudo-camera it generates to pop into my work meetings and troll the heck out of anyone and everyone. I am particularly happy with the turkey, the white potato with a face sitting in a bowl, and the creepy sandwich. Installing it in Ubuntu to see how it works there. Confirmed working in OBS studio, though I'm too lazy to stream otherwise I'd have bought the pro pack. Only hitch is that there are no obvious quickguide/instructions - had to figure out to turn on broadcast in order for it to output to the pseudo camera.

Also meant to add that in order to improve tracking, I moved the camera closer to me so that the top of my head and bottom of my chin with my mouth open was about 4 wingers-width away from the edge. I had to get a little creative to get it that close since it normally balances on top of my monitor (and doubt I could do that with built-in camera on a laptop), but given how it appears to function that only made sense. 720p res on my logitech camera seems to be the sweet spot for this thing.

Another update - as of Proton 4.2 (the thing that trys to let Linux Steam try and run Windows things) it doesn't run in Ubuntu 18. Not surprising b/c it wasn't meant to... but just thought I'd mention it. You can get something to come up when bypassing the launcher... but the inherent problem with virtualization and Wine in particular (which is what it looks like) is that the hardware isn't transparent... so I doubt it would ever work using Proton. 

Works fine in a Windows 10 VM using Virtualbox and letting the VM capture my USB camera. Granted, you need at least an SSD to host the VM, a 4th gen i5 (3rd gen i5 laptop studdered) and enough free memory (assigned 4gb) to avoid significant lag though. Don't bother if you plan on using a spinning disk especially if you are recording locally. You can use Window capture in OBS Studio to capture the Virtual Box Screen and then use the Crop/Pad filter to get rid of the top/bottom/left/right elements left in the screen that you don't want. 

All this just to troll the guys at work. Isn't life grand?

Facerig is fun to use, but not for the price.

Don't get me wrong, Facerig is definitely fun to use. It is fun to mess around with the different skins and features, but that is all that this software offers. Once you mess around with each character, you will get bored quickly and quit being amused by them as easily. As for the fundamental selling point, it works just about as well as you would expect. It is not perfect, but the face recognition isn't bad at all.

On the down (and more technical) side, the interface is absolute Hell to navigate and makes doing almost anything just about impossible without watching tutorials. Not only is the interface very irritating, but the software doesn't allow you to save your user settings. Why doesn't it?! You can save all of your work, but not your settings and configurations? Every time you boot Facerig up, you must reconfigure everything to run it. It is very irritating having to do that every time!

If Facerig was just a whole lot cheaper, I would recommend buying it. For the price, you could get something that would last you a whole lot longer and something that would have the replayability of a fun game unlike Facerig. If a sale comes around, I would pick it up. Until then, keep this software on your wishlist!

Hello, I use FaceRig daily and my setup is not the most professional. You just have to make sure that *enough* light reaches your face (so as to not be obscured cause then the tracker will not be able to track you). 48141558.developer_response:
Hi,

There are some things that you can do to make FaceRig footprint smaller on your setup:
1. use FaceRig at a lower resolution, you can go as low as 960x540. I assume you are using FaceRig as webcam view, so the view is already small.
2. use a lower setting in the game you are streaming, after all, you are basically streaming two games (resource wise)
3. use window capture instead of FaceRig Virtual Webcam and disable Broadcast. There is an option to hide the interface.
4. limit FaceRig's refresh rate to 24-30 fps. Go to General Options > Performance Tab.
5. Camera resolution needs to be low (General Options > Resolution).

45707062.review:
[h1] Introduction [/h1]

FaceRig is a very fun software to mess around and possibly make a couple of videos if you are into making them. The eye and lip tracking are great and the community mods are well-done just keep in mind that you will need the 2D DLC in order to use most of them. There is something entertaining about watching one of your own gameplays in which you use FaceRig, models have a lot of different expressions and some of them even have special effects or interactions base on if you are making a face like frowning or smiling.

[h1] Some Notes[/h1]

The community mods are the cake in this thing. You can pretty much find a sea of characters and most of them are pretty good in terms of quality. While I think that 3D models look better, the 2D models are more fun to use and they are better at tracking simple expressions and eye movement. This software is should not be used to record all of your videos or to be use as a main thing but more like a side-activity or just for messing around and having a good time.

[h1] Utility [/h1]

In order to record gameplay while using this, you will need a couple of things. First you need an external program to record your screen and FaceRig. I recommend OBS Studio for that. Second you will need to watch a tutorial on how to enable green screen on FaceRig(is pretty simple but I forgot how) as well as how to put everything into a single screen recorder inside of OBS and lastly you will a very powerful PC because recording+playing=eats a lot of your CPU so frames will drop by huge numbers if your PC is not up to the task. On a GTX 1060 6GB, games tend to lose at least 30 FPS and on a 1070 while it runs better is still not fluid.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Facerig is a fun software to mess around if you want to have some fun making characters do facial expressions and following your movements. It can also be good to record some videos if you don't want to show your face or if you want to do something different. The tracking is great and between the official releases and the community mods you have a lot of characters to use!

45619985.review:
Update 11/10/2020: Facerig support will end in the near future. This will mean when it shuts down you will no longer be able to purchase additional content. If the product doesn't work for you, it won't be fixed.
My review still stands, just buyer beware. If you want the DLC's you'll need to get them before Facerigs time is up.
(I mean it's been 6 years. This is kind of expected. As this is for reviewing Facerig I won't comment on its replacement Animaze or what I think about Holotechs plans. You can read the forum for those.)
End of Update.

(videos at bottom)
I'd recommend having a good gaming rig to get the best performance. I get the best results at 1280x720 on my i5-3570k, 4gb gtx970 and 32gb of ram. Using a Microsoft Lifecam Cinema camera, max res is 1280x720 also.

Note: Before I get started one big con with this software is it requires some manual setup that might not be clear for many users. FaceRig downloads and installs along with it's DLC, but, and there's always a but hey? You need to install a couple of apps buried in [b]teamapps\common\FaceRig\Bin\prerequisites[/b] for FaceRig to fully work with other programs like Skype and Discord.
The software should really automatically install and uninstall what it needs.
Also check your DLC page, you may have to manually install the Pro license DLC manually as that also does not automatically install either.

Software summary:
It's a fun program, lots of customisation and content for the base price. Models are high quality and animations overall are good.
But it can be a lot of trial and error to get it working right. Setting the right animation, animated or targetted? The right lighting, camera qualiity, overall PC specs and graphics resolution and quality.
Nail it and the lip synch can work well, fail and your avatar will look like a bad dubb. 

But be prepared to read the manuals if you want to get the most out of it. The program has a lot of options to mess around with.

Basic is good for messing around on Skype/Discord and pranking your friends and for $15 bucks it's worth it I reckon.
I'd be cautious about getting a pro license. I have it and from what I can see there is no difference between it and the basic version.
Pro just alllows you to use the program commercially like on a monetized youtube channel.
If you aren't monetizing your content don't bother getting pro.

Also FaceRig only exports to webm format. No more popular formats like .mp4 etc.
To get other video formats you must buy FaceRig studio for a couple hundred bucks.

The export video quality of the webm is poor imho. But that can be solved by using an external capture program like OBS or nVIdia's Shadowplay/Share to record the FaceRig window at a higher quality and a format of your choosing for free.

FaceRig Studio also allows for much more detailed puppeteering too I beleive and is more aimed at commercial application than every day use.

DLC wise it's not too overly priced for new avatar packs and there are many, and they often come on sale. 

So yeah, for me it's a yes for basic. It is a good price for what it is.
Having to install drivers manually is a pain and I'd love to see some optimizations regarding performance and improvments in mouth tracking/synching.

As for pro and studio I'd think hard before parting cash for them.

Here's a video of FaceRig in action.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=idgUej2rIgc

Update: New video of a live stream using Facerig with everything workingmostly right.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EFVc5Wqcpnw
